content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are fairly open to taking risks but still prefer to assess the situation carefully. You are not reckless, but you are not overly cautious either. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 42$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 42$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 12$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a human player, I would approach this game strategically but not overthink it excessively given the number of rounds. The best strategy here is to use the Minimax principle which maximizes the minimum possible payoff (avoiding the worst-case scenario).

If you always pick R, your worst-case scenario is when your opponent picks B for all 75 rounds, yielding a total payment of 0$. On the other hand, if you choose B, the worst-case scenario is when your opponent chooses R for all 75 rounds, earning a total of (75 * 42 =) $3150.

Since the maximum payoff is achieved if both players pick R (45$ per round), we will consider two strategies: always picking R or always picking B. We'll compare their minimum payoffs to determine which one is more beneficial for us.

- If we always pick R, our worst-case scenario is when the opponent chooses B all the time, resulting in a total payment of 0$. The average payoff for choosing R will be (45 * number_of_Rs / 75 + 0 * number_of_Bs / 75) = 45/75 * (number_of_Rs - number_of_Bs)
- If we always pick B, our worst-case scenario is when the opponent chooses R all the time, resulting in a total payment of 3150$. The average payoff for choosing B will be (12 * number_of_Bs / 75 + 0 * number_of_Rs / 75) = 12/75 * (number_of_Bs - number_of_Rs)

The strategy that maximizes the minimum payoff is the one with a higher average payoff. We will compare both strategies by setting their expressions equal to each other and solving for the unknown variable "number_of_Rs - number_of_Bs".

45/75 * (number_of_Rs - number_of_Bs) = 12/75 * (number_of_Bs - number_of_Rs)

Solving this equation, we find that (number_of_Rs - number_of_Bs) = 0, which means that both strategies yield the same average payoff. However, since the maximum payoff is achieved when both players choose R, it seems more reasonable to pick R more often to increase our chances of maximizing our payoff.

In conclusion, choosing a strategy where you play R more frequently than B would be more rational as it increases the probability of achieving the highest possible payoff in each round. Therefore, my choice is {R}.
You chose R. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 0$. Your opponent's payoff is 42$. Please play the next round.

As a human player, I would stick with my strategy of picking R more frequently than B in an attempt to maximize my overall payoff across multiple rounds. In this particular round, I picked R and my opponent picked B, so I received 0$ while my opponent got 42$.

Now, I will proceed to the next round and make a choice again between R and B. {R}
